this session is based on several engagements with my customers i had over time in
various stages of their azure adoption who needed to answer a relatively simple question
are you ready to go live with product a or service b on azure and if not what are we missing and how
can we fix it each customer case was very different in terms of

processes and tooling they they use so i picked some

in azure but i do hope that some of these lessons coming from practical customer

together maybe doing some all night or all weekend release but as an analogy it
still could serve the purpose simply because it all begins with what
what defines your production readiness
i believe that most of engineers like to have very measurable kpis or

this what something happens um there is also some consideration

once you actually have this definition in place of that monitoring strategy

is a holistic product that includes many features and can cover the
entire stack but maybe that's not what you what you need we have customers who like to bring

we also have seen many customers using third-party products for specific
functions like application performance monitoring cm for security and itsm
for service management so it's important to know that even though azure monitor is
a very emphasized solution as a as your native one it is also an open ecosystem
and you can bring any tool that you you like you don't need to change

want to make sure that you get it somewhere else where you want to analyze and visualize and maybe

actually did embrace azure monitor and and started looking into how can we
how can we build this monitoring architecture so there are a couple of uh
considerations that we that we have to have to make in azure monitor everything that is uh that you collect
and it could be either metrics or logs is stored in azure monitor workspace and you can have
several workspaces uh scattered across your subscriptions and if you have an environment with uh
with dozens of subscriptions then you start wondering what's the best model should i have one central
workspace or should i have one per subscription or one per application
and for a long time there wasn't really a good way how you can centralize and consolidate so there were
three possible design patterns either a centralized with one or the fewer subscript
workspaces as possible then they were decentralized or distributed and then something like
hybrid where people were actually collecting uh logs several times which is not very good from the cost
perspective but that's what they hear what they needed but microsoft definitely recommends
these days to use centralized deployment model if possible uh and there are several uh reasons for
that one is that you should avoid a so-called multi-homing
uh set up for azure vms first of all uh and what does it mean it
means that you can send telemetry to multiple workspaces from uh from your azure virtual machine first of all
it's supported only on windows vms or on linux vms you can only send to one workspace
and the recent changes in application insights for those of you who like to use
that product for application level monitoring uh also allow you to now to consolidate both
application and infrastructure or platform telemetry into one single workspace which wasn't possible
before every time you spin up an app insights it created its own workspace so now you
can actually have that in in one single repository
the second fact that allows my customers to start with consolidation was that
azure monitor introduced resource level permissions which is the new access control mode
what it allows you uh is that you can actually really consolidate the logs in one place
but um your visibility to uh to that repository will be based on
what permissions you had in those original resources that are sending that telemetry to the workspace
it means that you can apply granular back without compromising compromising security and of course
if you have one or just a few workspaces it simplifies uh cross-resource queries
if you want to build uh complex queries uh using kql or gusto query language
so that was the first design that we that we applied in in that

you can either choose that or you can send the data to your azure blob storage which is typically
